title: 107_hr4081
content: Federal contractors must have a satisfactory record of integrity and business ethics. Federal contractors must have a satisfactory record of integrity and business ethics, including compliance with various laws such as tax, labor, environmental, antitrust, and consumer protection laws. A contracting officer must determine this before awarding a contract. The contracting officer must consider all relevant information, giving the most weight to adjudicated law violations in the past 3 years by the prospective contractor. Administrative agreements with corrective actions may also be taken into account. Failure to comply with such agreements is seen as a lack of integrity. Other relevant information, like civil or administrative complaints, may also be considered. The contracting officer must consider relevant information, giving most weight to adjudicated law violations in the past 3 years by the prospective contractor. This includes convictions, civil judgments, and administrative complaints related to fraud, criminal offenses, antitrust violations, and embezzlement. This also includes indictments for various offenses and adverse judgments or decisions related to tax, labor, employment, environmental, antitrust, or consumer protection laws. The table of sections in the chapter is amended to include a new item related to federal or state felony indictments. The Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949 is amended to include a new section requiring contractors to have a satisfactory record of integrity and business ethics. The Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949 is amended to mandate that prospective contractors must have a satisfactory record of integrity and business ethics, including compliance with various laws. Contracting officers must consider violations of law adjudicated in the past three years with the most weight, along with any administrative agreements with the contractor. The Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949 requires prospective contractors to have a good record of integrity and business ethics. Contracting officers must consider past violations of law, corrective actions taken, and failure to comply with administrative agreements when evaluating a contractor's responsibility. Other relevant information, such as civil or administrative complaints, may also be taken into account. The Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949 mandates that prospective contractors must have a clean record of integrity and business ethics. Contracting officers must assess past convictions, civil judgments, and indictments related to fraud, criminal offenses, antitrust violations, embezzlement, theft, forgery, bribery, falsification, tax evasion, and receiving stolen property when evaluating a contractor's suitability. The Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949 requires contractors to have a clean record regarding tax, labor, employment, environmental, antitrust, or consumer protection laws. This includes felony convictions, adverse court judgments, administrative law violations, and felony indictments. The amendments made by this section require contractors to have a satisfactory record of integrity and business ethics for contracts issued after the enactment of this Act.
